{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Matmut Stadium de Gerland | nickname = | image = [[Image:Stade-Gerland-RWC2007.JPG|250px]] '''[[UEFA stadium categories|UEFA]]''' [[Image:Nuvola apps mozilla.png|12px]][[Image:Nuvola apps mozilla.png|12px]][[Image:Nuvola apps mozilla.png|12px]][[Image:Nuvola apps mozilla.png|12px]] | fullname = Stade de Gerland | location = 353, Avenue Jean-Jaurès, 69007 [[7th arrondissement of Lyon|VIIè Arrondissement]], [[Lyon]], [[France]] | coordinates = {{Coord|45|43|26|N|4|49|56|E|type:landmark_scale:2000|display=it}} | broke_ground = | built = 1914 | opened = 1926 | renovated = | expanded = 1960, 1980, 1998 | closed = | demolished = | owner = City of [[Lyon]] | operator = [[Lyon OU]] | surface = [[Grass]] | construction_cost = 32.7m [[Euro|€]]
(including renovations) | architect = [[Tony Garnier (architect)|Tony Garnier]]
[[René Gagis]] (renovation) | general_contractor= | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = | tenants = [[Olympique Lyonnais]] (1950–2015)
[[Lyon OU]] (2017–present) | seating_capacity = 25,000 | dimensions = 105 x 68 m }} The '''Stade de Gerland''' (known for sponsorship reasons as '''Matmut Stadium de Gerland''' and otherwise known as '''Municipal de Gerland''' or '''Stade Gerland''' {{IPA-fr|stad ʒɛʁlɑ̃|}}) is a stadium in the city of [[Lyon]], [[France]] which serves as home to [[Top 14]] rugby club [[Lyon OU]]. It has a seating capacity of 25,000. Situated in the [[Gerland, Lyon|Gerland]] quarter, it was used by French professional [[Association football|football]] club [[Olympique Lyonnais]], who moved to the newly constructed [[Parc Olympique Lyonnais]] in 2016. Local rugby union club [[Lyon OU]] moved in beginning of 2017, replacing their much smaller stadium [[Matmut Stadium]]. The stadium's capacity was also reduced from 43,000 to a more reasonable 25,000. The Stade de Gerland is listed as a [[UEFA stadium categories|Category three]] stadium by [[UEFA]]'s standards and has hosted matches for the [[1972 Rugby League World Cup]], [[UEFA Euro 1984]], the [[1998 FIFA World Cup]], and the [[2007 Rugby World Cup]]. The stadium has hosted concerts by many famous artists, including [[The Rolling Stones]], [[Michael Jackson]], [[David Bowie]], [[Pink Floyd]] and [[Genesis (band)|Genesis]]. Former president Nicholas Sarkozy played at this arena with his rock band when he was a teenager, before getting involved in politics. ==History== In 1910, the mayor of [[Lyon]], [[Édouard Herriot]], came up with the idea to develop and build a sports stadium with an [[Track and field athletics|athletics]] track and a [[velodrome]] in the city. In 1912, the stadium was officially mandated and local [[architect]] [[Tony Garnier (architect)|Tony Garnier]] was given the reins to designing and constructing it. Construction began in 1914 with hopes that the stadium would be completed before the [[World's fair|International Exhibition of 1914]]. However, due to World War I, construction was temporarily halted, but resumed following the wars conclusion in 1919 with the assistance of a large number of German [[prisoner of war|POWs]]. By 1920, the stadium was completely functional. In 1926, the Stade de Gerland was inaugurated by Herriot. The stadium originally had a [[cycling]] track, but it was removed in order to increase the seating capacity to 50,000. In 1984, minor renovations were made to the stadium by architect Rene Gagis in order to bring the stadium up to standards for [[UEFA Euro 1984]]. This included construction of the [[Jean Bouin]] and [[Jean Jaurès]] stands. Further renovations were needed to prepare the stadium for the [[1998 FIFA World Cup]], as by that time [[FIFA]] had mandated that all stadiums used for international matches, including the [[Football World Cup|World Cup]], had to be [[all-seater|all-seated]]. The north and south stands were completely dismantled and rebuilt, the [[Jean Jaurès]] and [[Jean Bouin]] side stands were untouched and the [[athletics (track and field)|athletics]] track that had remained, even after the cycling track had been removed, was taken out. The renovations were done by architect Albert Constantin. The new incarnation of Gerland had a maximum capacity of 40,500. Since 1950 the stadium has been home to French professional [[Association football|football]] club [[Olympique Lyonnais]] who play in [[Ligue 1]], France's highest football division. Lyon moved into the stadium as a result of splitting from the [[Lyon OU|Lyon Olympique Universitaire]] sport club, which played at the Stade des Iris. The record attendance for a [[Ligue 1]] match is 48,552 for a derby match between Olympique Lyonnais and [[AS Saint-Étienne]] in 1982. During the [[2003 FIFA Confederations Cup]] semi-final at the stadium between [[Cameroon national football team|Cameroon]] and [[Colombia national football team|Colombia]], Cameroon midfielder [[Marc-Vivien Foé]] collapsed on the pitch and died shortly afterwards in hospital.{{cite news | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/3024360.stm | title = Cameroon star Foe dies | publisher = BBC Sport| accessdate = 5 January 2008 | date=26 June 2003}} ==Artists== Gerland is also used for events of mass such as The [[Rolling Stones]]'s concerts, [[Michael Jackson]], [[Pink Floyd]], [[Johnny Hallyday]], [[Genesis (band)|Genesis]]. ==UEFA Euro 1984== The stadium was one of the venues of the [[UEFA Euro 1984]], and held the following matches: {{clear}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: left;" width="100%" |- !Date !Team #1 !Res. !Team #2 !Round !Attendance |- |16 June 1984 || {{fb|DEN}} || style="text-align:center;"|5–0 || {{fb|YUG}} || Group A || style="text-align:center;"| 24,736 |- |24 June 1984 || {{fb|SPA}} || style="text-align:center;"|1–1 (5–4 [[penalty shoot-out (association football)|pen.]]) || {{fb|DEN}} || Semi-finals || style="text-align:center;"| 47,843 |} ==1998 FIFA World Cup== The stadium was one of the venues of the [[1998 FIFA World Cup]], and held the following matches: {{clear}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: left;" width="100%" |- !Date !Team #1 !Res. !Team #2 !Round !Attendance |- |13 June 1998 || {{fb|KOR|1997}} || style="text-align:center;"|1–3 || {{fb|MEX}} || Group E || style="text-align:center;"| 39,100 |- |15 June 1998 || {{fb|ROM}} || style="text-align:center;"|1–0 || {{fb|COL}} || Group G || style="text-align:center;"| 39,100 |- |21 June 1998 || {{fb|USA}} || style="text-align:center;"|1–2 || {{fb|IRN}} || Group F || style="text-align:center;"| 39,100 |- |24 June 1998 || {{fb|FRA}} || style="text-align:center;"|2–1 || {{fb|DEN}} || Group C || style="text-align:center;"| 39,100 |- |26 June 1998 || {{fb|JPN|1870}} || style="text-align:center;"|1–2 || {{fb|JAM}} || Group H || style="text-align:center;"| 39,100 |- |4 July 1998 || {{fb|GER}} || style="text-align:center;"|0–3 || {{fb|CRO}} || Quarter-finals || style="text-align:center;"| 39,100 |} ==2003 FIFA Confederations Cup== The stadium was one of the venues of the [[2003 FIFA Confederations Cup]], and held the following matches: {{clear}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: left;" width="100%" |- !Date !Team #1 !Res. !Team #2 !Round !Attendance |- |18 June 2003 || {{fb|FRA}} || style="text-align:center;"|1–0 || {{fb|COL}} || Group A || style="text-align:center;"| 38,541 |- |20 June 2003 || {{fb|COL}} || style="text-align:center;"|3–1 || {{fb|NZL}} || Group A || style="text-align:center;"| 22,811 |- |21 June 2003 || {{fb|BRA}} || style="text-align:center;"|1–0 || {{fb|USA}} || Group B || style="text-align:center;"| 20,306 |- |23 June 2003 || {{fb|USA}} || style="text-align:center;"|0–0 || {{fb|CMR}} || Group B || style="text-align:center;"| 19,206 |- |26 June 2003 || {{fb|CMR}} || style="text-align:center;"|1–0 || {{fb|COL}} || Semi-finals || style="text-align:center;"| 12,352 |} ==2007 Rugby World Cup== The stadium hosted three pool matches in the [[2007 Rugby World Cup]]: [[Australia national rugby union team|Australia]] vs [[Japan national rugby union team|Japan]], [[Argentina national rugby union team|Argentina]] vs [[Georgia national rugby union team|Georgia]] and [[New Zealand national rugby union team|New Zealand]] vs [[Portugal national rugby union team|Portugal]]. ==Rugby League== Stade de Gerland played host to the [[1972 Rugby League World Cup]] Final between [[Great Britain Lions|Great Britain]] and [[Australian Kangaroos|Australia]]. The French public seemed uninterested in a final that did not involve the [[France national rugby league team|French]] team, as only 4,231 spectators turned up. The game will always be remembered by the British for their captain [[Clive Sullivan]]'s wonderful long distance try, and by the Australians for perhaps "The greatest try never scored", later shown on TV to be legitimately scored by Australian fullback [[Graeme Langlands]], but disallowed by French referee Georges Jameau who believed him to be offside (TV footage indicated Langlands had been approximately one metre behind halfback [[Dennis Ward (rugby league)|Dennis Ward]] as he put up his kick). Lions hooker [[Mike Stephenson]] scored the 73rd-minute try that helped Great Britain level the scores and secure the World Cup. Had Aussie winger [[Ray Branighan]] succeeded with a 79th-minute penalty, or [[Bob Fulton]] landed one of three drop goal attempts in the last five minutes, the cup could easily have gone to Australia. But for the first time in the competition's history the scores were level at full time. An additional twenty minutes extra time was played, but no further score resulted, and Great Britain were awarded the cup by virtue of a better W-L record and due to having defeated Australia earlier in the tournament.[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=g6QneX1iBrI 1972 Rugby League World Cup Final highlights] ==See also== * [[Parc de Gerland]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Stade de Gerland}} * [http://www.lyon.fr/lieu/sport/stade-de-gerland.html Official website] {{s-start}} {{succession box | title=[[Rugby League World Cup]]
[[Rugby League World Cup finals|Final venue]] | before=[[Headingley Carnegie Rugby Stadium|Headingley]]
[[1970 Rugby League World Cup Final|1970]] | after=[[Sydney Cricket Ground]]
[[1977 Rugby League World Cup Final|1977]] | years=[[1972 Rugby League World Cup Final|1972]] | }} {{succession box | title=[[European Cup Winners Cup]]
[[UEFA Cup Winners' Cup finals|Final Venue]]| before=[[De Kuip]]
[[Rotterdam]]| after=[[Olympic Stadium (Athens)|Spiros Louis Stadium]]
[[Athens]]| years=[[UEFA Cup Winners' Cup 1985-86|1986]] }} {{s-end}} {{Olympique Lyonnais}} {{1938 FIFA World Cup stadiums}} {{1954 RLWC Venues}} {{1972 RLWC Venues}} {{1998 FIFA World Cup Venues}} {{2007 Rugby World Cup Venues}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Stade De Gerland}} [[Category:7th arrondissement of Lyon]] [[Category:1938 FIFA World Cup stadiums]] {{UEFA Euro 1984 stadiums}} [[Category:1998 FIFA World Cup stadiums]] [[Category:2003 FIFA Confederations Cup stadiums]] [[Category:UEFA Euro 1984 stadiums|Gerland]] [[Category:Football venues in France|Gerland]] [[Category:Rugby union stadiums in France|Gerland]] [[Category:Rugby World Cup stadiums|Gerland]] [[Category:Rugby League World Cup stadiums]] [[Category:Olympique Lyonnais]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Lyon]] [[Category:Sports venues in Rhône (department)]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1926]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} {{Infobox stadium |stadium_name = Stebonheath Park |nickname = Stebo |image = Stebonheath Park - geograph-265938.jpg |image_size = 250px |location = Evans Terrace, [[Llanelli]], [[Carmarthenshire]], [[Wales]] SA15 1EY |capacity = 3,700 (1,005 seated) |opened = |closed = |demolished = |owner = [[Llanelli Town Council]] |operator = [[Llanelli A.F.C.]] |surface = Grass |construction_cost = |architect = |former_names = |tenants = {{infobox stadium/tenantlist |tenant_clubs = [[Llanelli A.F.C.]]
Llanelli AAC
[[Raiders RL]] |tenant_years = 19??-2013
1979-present
2015-present}} }} '''Stebonheath Park''' (''[[Welsh language|Welsh]]: Parc Stebonheath'') is a multi-use [[stadium]] in [[Llanelli]], [[West Wales]] with a capacity of 3,700. It is primarily used as a [[Association football|football]] ground and is the home of [[Llanelli Town A.F.C.]]. It was also used for athletics and Llanelli Amateur Athletic Club (Llanelli AAC) were based at the stadium. It is owned by [[Llanelli Town Council]]. From 2015 [[Raiders RL]] club used the stadium for their debut season in the [[Conference League South]] but are now based at the park on a permanent basis as they compete in the RFL professional tier as the only professional Rugby League team in South Wales. ==History== Stebonheath Park has been used as a football ground since 1920.{{cite web|url=http://www.llanellitowncouncil.gov.uk/football.htm|title=Football & Athletics - Stebonheath Park|publisher=[[Llanelli Town Council]]|accessdate=31 October 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090105215838/http://www.llanellitowncouncil.gov.uk/football.htm|archivedate=5 January 2009|df=dmy-all}} It almost hosted League football in the 1930s but the club lost out coming second in the vote. At the time the ground had a large wooden grandstand, a covered end terrace and a large bank on the south side, and it could easily have been developed into a Third Division ground.{{Citation needed|date=October 2008}} The stand was subsequently demolished and the ground re-shaped to allow the building of an adjacent by-pass road.{{Citation needed|date=October 2008}} Stebonheath Park was home to the [[Wales national rugby league team]] in the 1930s. Here Wales were crowned European Champions, after defeating England 17–9, on 10 November 1938. [[Frank Whitcombe]] made his debut for Wales in this game. The stadium has been owned by Llanelli Town Council since 1977. The council undertook major redevelopmemts of the stadium which included [[Floodlights (sport)|floodlighting]], a new 700 seater main stand, new terracing, a function room social club as well as all-weather training facilities for the athletics club.{{cite web|url=http://www.welshpremier.com/stebonheath.ink|title=Stebonheath Report|date=23 January 2007|publisher=Welsh Premier Football|accessdate=31 October 2008}} In July 2008, a new open seated stand was built on existing terracing along one side of the ground with about 300 seats.{{Citation needed|date=October 2008}} Around the pitch is a narrow 400 metre running track with four lanes on each straight. It is the narrowest 400m track in the [[United Kingdom]].{{cite web|url=http://www.runtrackdir.com/details.asp?track=llanelli|title=Stebonheath Park Track|date=12 January 2002|publisher=UK Running Track Directory|accessdate=31 October 2008}} On 28 February 2006 the stadium hosted an international match between [[Wales national under-21 football team|Wales Under-21s]] and [[Northern Ireland national under-21 football team|Northern Ireland Under-21s]], with the Northern Irish side winning 1-0.{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/internationals/4755876.stm|title=Wales U21 0-1 N Ireland U21|date=28 February 2006|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|accessdate=31 October 2008}} Local junior football finals are held at the stadium.{{Citation needed|date=October 2008}} The [[Welsh Cup]] Final has been staged at the stadium including the 2002-03 season final between [[Barry Town F.C.|Barry Town]] and [[Cwmbran Town A.F.C.|Cwmbran Town]] as well as the 2004-05 final between [[The New Saints F.C.|Total Network Solutions]] and [[Carmarthen Town A.F.C.|Carmarthen Town]].{{cite web|url=http://www.welsh-premier.com/news.php?ID=2417|title=TNS face long haul for final|date=12 April 2005|publisher=Welsh Premier Football|accessdate=31 October 2008}} On 6 May 2007 Stebonheath Park staged the 120th Welsh Cup final between Carmarthen Town and [[Afan Lido F.C.|Afan Lido]].{{cite web|url=http://www.carmarthentownafc.net/april07WC.htm|title=Carmarthen 3-2 Afan Lido|date=6 May 2007|publisher=[[Carmarthen Town A.F.C.]]|accessdate=31 October 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080914193726/http://www.carmarthentownafc.net/april07WC.htm|archivedate=14 September 2008|df=dmy-all}} On 31 October 2008 the stadium hosted a [[Victory Shield]] [[2008 Victory Shield|match]] between Wales under-16 and [[England national under-16 football team|England under-16]] which was shown live on [[Sky Sports]].{{cite web|url=http://www.thefa.com/England/U16s/NewsAndFeatures/Postings/2008/10/U16vWales_match_report.htm|archive-url=https://archive.is/20081218011251/http://www.thefa.com/England/U16s/NewsAndFeatures/Postings/2008/10/U16vWales_match_report.htm|dead-url=yes|archive-date=18 December 2008|title=Afobe wins it for Lions|last=Lavery|first=Glen|date=31 October 2008|publisher=[[The Football Association]]|accessdate=31 October 2008}} In 2016 it held a [[2017 Rugby League World Cup qualification – Europe#Game 2|2017 Rugby League World Cup Qualifier]] between Wales and Serbia.{{cite web|title=WALES TO TAKE ON SERBIA IN LLANELLI|url=http://www.walesrugbyleague.co.uk/article/14328/wales-to-take-on-serbia|publisher=walesrugbyleague.co.uk|accessdate=23 March 2016}} ==Llanelli AFC== Although the stadium was the home of Llanelli AFC, they used to play major games at [[Stradey Park]] which had a capacity of 10,800. Stradey Park was demolished in late 2008 and an option for major games was the then newly built 14,340 capacity [[Parc y Scarlets]]. The new open seated stand at Stebonheath Park enabled Llanelli to host European matches, the first being a [[UEFA Champions League]] qualifier against [[Latvia]]n club [[FK Ventspils]] in July 2008. ==Llanelli AAC== Lanelli AAC, which was formed in 1978, is based at the stadium and caters for all standards of [[Track and field|track and field athletics]], [[cross-country running]] and [[road running]].{{cite web|url=http://www.llanelliaac.co.uk|title=Llanelli Athletic Club|publisher=Llanelli Athletic Club|accessdate=31 October 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080515164441/http://www.llanelliaac.co.uk/|archivedate=15 May 2008|df=dmy-all}} ==Raiders RL== West Wales Raiders RL relocated to Llanelli in 2014 and struck up a deal to play at the stadium with the local council in preparation for the debut season in the Conference league south where they finished 3rd. The West Wales Raiders Rugby League Club previously known as Raiders RL are the most established Rugby league club[1] in West Wales formed in January 2015.[2] Formerly called Gwendreath Valley Raiders they moved to Llanelli when the club gained entry into the Conference League South which is level 4 of the Rugby League system. In 2017, Andrew Thorne purchased the semi professional League 1 club South Wales Ironmen, relocating the club immediately to Llanelli. The Ironmen will rebrand as West Wales Raiders from 2018 onwards. They also have links with one of the oldest university rugby league teams in Wales the Warpigs from Swansea University. The raiders have taken over the running and coaching of the university rugby league team since 2017. The Raiders first ever match was an away friendly against Aberystwyth University in February which they won 72-6. Their first league match was a home derby win against the defending champions Valley Cougars 34-6, captain Alan Pope scoring the clubs first try. The game was watched by over 370 spectators.[citation needed] ==Records== The record attendance at Stebonheath Park is 1,410 for a [[Welsh Premier League]] football match between Llanelli and Barry Town on 14 January 2000.{{cite web|url=http://www.welsh-premier.com/sa_stadium.php?cid=11 |title=Stebonheath Park |publisher=Welsh Premier Football |accessdate=31 October 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070211025826/http://www.welsh-premier.com/sa_stadium.php?cid=11 |archivedate=11 February 2007 }} ==References== {{reflist}} {{coord|51.6839|N|4.1476|W|source:dewiki_region:GB-CMN_type:landmark|format=dms|display=title}} [[Category:Sport in Llanelli]] [[Category:Llanelli Town A.F.C.]] [[Category:Football venues in Wales]] [[Category:Welsh Cup final venues]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Carmarthenshire]] [[Category:Stadiums in Llanelli]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1920]] [[Category:Rugby league stadiums in Wales]]

{{Infobox football club | clubname = USM Oran
إتحاد وهران | image = USM Oran (logo).png | fullname = Union Sportive Madinet d'Oran
إتحاد رياضي مدينة وهران | nickname = ''Le Doyen
Unionistes'' | founded = {{start date and age|1926|March|1|df=yes|p=yes}} | ground = [[Stade Allal Toula]]
[[Oran]], [[Algeria]] | capacity = 5,000 | chrtitle = President | chairman = Mokhtar Boughrassa | mgrtitle = Head Coach | manager = |league = [[Inter-Régions Division]] |season = [[2017–18 Inter-Régions Division|2017–18]] |position = |current = 2018–19 USM Oran season | pattern_la1 = _blackborder | pattern_b1 = | pattern_ra1 = _blackborder | leftarm1 = FFFFFF | body1 = FFFFFF | rightarm1 = FFFFFF | shorts1 = FFFFFF | socks1 = 000000 | pattern_la2 = _whiteborder | pattern_b2 = | pattern_ra2 = _whiteborder | leftarm2 = 000000 | body2 = 000000 | rightarm2 = 000000 | shorts2 = 000000 | socks2 = FFFFFF }} '''Union Sportive Madinet d'Oran''' ({{lang-ar|الإتحاد الرياضي لمدينة وهران}}), known as '''USM Oran''' or simply '''USMO''' for short, is an [[Algeria]]n football club based in [[Oran]]. The club was founded in 1926 and its colours are black and white. Their home stadium, [[Stade Allal Toula]], has a capacity of 5,000 spectators. The club is currently playing in the [[Inter-Régions Division]]. ==History== [[Image:USM Oran (1939).jpg|left|250px|thumb|USM Oran in 1939]] The club was founded on March 1, 1926 under the name of Union Sportive Musulmane d'Oran in Medina Jedida, a famous popular quarter of [[Oran]], by the Algerian nationalist Sadek Boumaza with Bendouba "El Fellous", Benkoula, Boumefraa and others. They decided to create a team which became a multi-sports club some days after its creation. The club is the first one of North Africa to put the word ''Musulmane'' ({{lang-en|Muslim}}) in its name to differentiate from other European colonial teams{{cite web |url=http://www.djazairess.com/fr/lexpression/34421 |title=USM Oran : Les " Noir et Blanc " en couleur |work=L'Expression Magazine |publisher=A. Salim |date=May 3, 2006 |accessdate= }}. The club was also named NADIT Oran between 1977 and 1989 ==Crest==
File:USM Oran (old logo).png|Old logo File:USM Oran (logo).jpg|Former logo File:USM Oran (logo).png|Present logo
==Stadium== The team plays in the '''Stade Allal Toula''' which holds 5,000 people. ==Achievements== ===National=== *'''[[League of Oran Football Association|League of Oran]]''' :Champion (7) : 1933, 1943, 1944, 1945, 1946, 1949, 1950 *'''Oran Cup''' :Winner (1) : 1952 ===Regional=== *'''[[North African Championship]]''' :Runner-up (3) : 1933, 1935, 1950 *'''[[North African Cup]]''' :Runner-up (1)
